Sold Strollers: Refers exclusively to revenue-generating transactions for strollers, requiring a filter on account_type in ('Income', 'Other Income') via a join with the chart of accounts to confirm the transaction represents a sale, not returns, adjustments, or internal transfers.
Expense account: An expense account must be confirmed by joining with the chart_of_accounts table to ensure the account type is 'Expense' or 'Other Expense', as transaction labels or debit activity alone are insufficient to classify an account as an expense.
Last quarter: Refers to the most recently completed calendar or fiscal quarter—defined by fixed quarterly boundaries such as Q1: January–March—determined dynamically relative to the current date; must be filtered using quarter-aware date logic that computes the exact start and end dates of the prior quarter, not as a rolling 90-day or 3-month window from today.
Sold to: Refers to outbound sales transactions such as invoices or sales receipts issued to the specified customer, filtered by customer identifier and transaction_type in ('invoice', 'sales receipt') while excluding returns, voids, and other non-sale transaction types.
Monthly spend on [Vendor]: Aggregate total 'debit' amounts by calendar month for transactions associated with the specified vendor, using date truncation to the start of each month for grouping; do not restrict to the current month or involve customer-related tables.
In Q3 last year: Filter records to the third quarter (July 1 to September 30) of the prior calendar year using relative date arithmetic from the current date—such as truncating to the start of last year and adding six months—without hardcoding any absolute dates; ensure correct temporal alignment by deriving the period dynamically and reference customer data directly from the transaction table if available to avoid erroneous joins.
Biggest expense: Identify the account with the highest cumulative sum of debit (or negative) amounts over a period, restricted to accounts classified as 'Expense' or 'Other Expense' in the chart_of_accounts, by aggregating outflows per account and excluding non-expense types; this is not determined by a single transaction amount or by summing across all account types indiscriminately.
This fiscal year: Refers to the current fiscal year-to-date period, dynamically calculated from the organization's fiscal year start date (e.g., April 1 or July 1) using relative date functions anchored to current_date, ensuring alignment with the correct fiscal calendar without hardcoded ranges or rolling 12-month assumptions.
In This year: Refers to transactions occurring from January 1st of the current calendar year up to and including the current date, accurately captured using transaction_date BETWEEN date('now', 'start of year') AND date('now') to ensure precise boundary inclusion and avoid reliance on strftime or implicit date handling.
Expense accounts: Identify expense accounts by joining transactions with the chart_of_accounts table and filtering for account_type IN ('Expense', 'Other Expense') to ensure only genuine outflows are included; this filter is required because debit activity alone does not signify an expense, as it can also increase assets or reduce liabilities.
In May last year: Filter records to include only those occurring within the full calendar month of May (from May 1 to May 31) of the previous calendar year, using dynamic date arithmetic—such as adjusting the current date by one year and setting the month to May with precise start and end boundaries—to avoid hardcoded values and ensure correct temporal alignment for timestamps with time components.
This month: Filter records from the start of the current calendar month to the current date inclusive, using date('now', 'start of month') for the lower bound and date('now') for the upper bound to ensure accurate time-range confinement within the present month.
Spend: Spend represents the sum of debit amounts or negative values in the 'Amount' field from transactions in accounts explicitly classified as 'Expense' or 'Other Expense', excluding all revenue-related, asset, liability, or equity accounts and ensuring only outflows are aggregated according to schema-specific conventions.
Last 12 months: Refers to the 12 completed calendar months, defined from the first day of the month 12 months prior to the current date to the last day of the previous month, using date truncation for alignment with standard financial reporting periods; must be combined with appropriate filters for transaction type, account category, and invoice status to ensure accurate aggregation in business context.
Mean invoice value: Calculate the average of the 'credit' field across transactions where transaction_type = 'invoice', explicitly excluding non-invoice transactions to prevent distortion; using any other field or omitting the filter invalidates the result.
Invoices created for Service: Identify transactions where transaction_type = 'invoice' and the associated service context is confirmed through pattern matching (e.g., using instr) in account, description, or similar text fields, rather than relying solely on exact matches in a Product_Service column to ensure comprehensive and accurate service linkage.
Last 7 days: Refers to the inclusive date range from midnight 7 days ago to the latest timestamp of the current day; implement using Transaction_DATE >= DATE('now', '-6 days') AND Transaction_DATE <= DATE('now', '23:59:59') to ensure precise calendar-day alignment, bounded filtering, and exclusion of future dates.
Last month: Refers exclusively to the full prior calendar month, defined as the period starting at the first day of the previous month and ending at the last day of that same month, computed using deterministic date arithmetic such as 'start of month' minus one month for the start and 'start of month' minus one day for the end; explicitly excludes any rolling 30-day or relative time window ending on the current date.
Bill received from: Indicates a transaction where the customer is the recipient and the vendor is the sender, with transaction_type = 'bill' and proper alignment of vendor-customer roles in joins; specifically represents an outgoing charge to the customer (credit to the vendor), requiring both correct role assignment and classification as a bill.
This year to date: Refers to valid sales transactions from the start of the current calendar year (January 1) to the current date, inclusive, using date('now', 'start of year') as the lower bound and current_date as the upper bound; explicitly excludes rolling periods and requires filtering for confirmed, non-adjusting transactions only.
Types of fund investments: Refers to the 'investmenttype' column in the database schema, which categorizes funds by their investment type; SQL queries must group by this specific column to correctly calculate metrics per investment type.
Highest number of holdings in bond categ: Requires counting the number of individual bond holding records per fund-manager pair from a detailed holdings table (e.g., mf_bondportifoliodetail), not using a precomputed or aggregated numeric field like BondFundN.
Top ten funds and managers: Implies the SQL must return both the fund name (e.g., secuabbr) and manager name (e.g., manager), derived through grouping by both fund and manager identifiers before ordering by the count of holdings.
Stocks and monthly time periods: Requires selecting both the stock identifier/name and the corresponding time period (e.g., enddate) to reflect when the financial criteria were met, not just the stock information alone.
Gross profit margin: Refers to the financial ratio calculated as (GrossProfit / OperatingRevenue), not the absolute 'GrossProfit' value. A margin greater than 1 implies a ratio exceeding 100%, which requires division, not direct comparison of gross profit amounts.
Established after 2010: Requires extracting the year component from EstablishmentDate using a function like strftime('%Y', date) and comparing it numerically to '2010', to ensure only companies founded from 2011 onward are included. Direct comparison of a date column to a string '2010' is ambiguous and unreliable.
Implemented dividend distribution: Indicated by the presence of a non-null DividendImplementDate in the lc_dividend table, which should be used as a filter condition to confirm actual dividend payout execution.
Major shareholders in the rights issue: Refers to shareholders participating in a rights offering, specifically those with share allocations recorded in a subscription or commitment table (e.g., 'lc_largeshsubscription'), not distribution tables.
Largest shareholder with the most rights: Implies finding the shareholder with the highest actual subscription or allocation in rights issuance events during the specified year, determined by aggregating or maximizing values like 'actualshares' from event-based tables, not selecting the highest 'HoldingPCT' from static ownership records.
Holdings for 21国债01: Refers to positions in a specific bond issue, identified by bond code '21国债01' in bond holding tables using the correct column (e.g., bondabbr or bond code), not StockCode in stock-centric tables.
Year-on-year changes in operating income: Refers to the 'MainIncomeGrowRateYOY' field, which directly represents the year-over-year growth rate of operating income and should be filtered for negative values to identify declines.
Establishment date is after 2015: Requires extracting the year from the date using a function like strftime('%Y', EstablishmentDate) and comparing it numerically to '2015', rather than comparing the full date string directly to '2015'.
Registered capital is greater than 2 bil: Means RegCapital > 2000000000, where the value must be treated as a numeric literal (without quotes) to ensure correct numerical comparison and avoid implicit string coercion risks.
Largest registered capital: Implies ordering by 'RegCapital' in descending order and limiting to one result to ensure a single fund manager is returned, rather than using a subquery with equality that may return multiple rows in case of ties.
Abbreviation of the fund manager: The required field 'InvestAdvisorAbbrName' is directly available in the 'mf_investadvisoroutline' table; no join with 'mf_personalinfo' is needed, as such joins may introduce incorrect or redundant data if relationships are not strictly 1:1.
Top ten funds, fund managers, and risk-r: Refers to returning only the fund identifier (e.g., SecuAbbr), the fund manager's name, and the descriptive risk-return type (e.g., 'aggressive', 'conservative'), not supporting codes or metrics like SecuCode, PersonalCode, RiskLevel, or the benchmark growth rate value itself.
Highest returns among funds: Implies ordering by the return metric (e.g., fundreturn) in descending order and limiting to the top result only after applying all filtering conditions, ensuring the ranking is done within the correctly filtered subset.
Company with the highest proportion of b: Refers to the entity identified by its official or abbreviated name (e.g., 'ChiNameAbbr') in the dividend table, not a full or alternative name field like 'ChiName', which may not represent the standardized company identifier used in financial disclosures.
Bonus share ratio in history: Requires retrieving the maximum value of 'BonusShareRatio' from the historical records in lc_dividend, ensuring the result reflects the single highest ratio ever recorded along with the corresponding company's correct identifier.
Major shareholder in the rights offering: Refers to shareholders participating in a specific capital event (rights issue) and requires querying a table that records large shareholder subscriptions (e.g., 'lc_largeshsubscription'), not general related-party shareholders.
Stock codes start with 6: Refers to filtering on the security code (e.g., secucode) field with a prefix '6', not joining through company-level codes or other indirect keys which may lead to incorrect associations.
Listed companies' stock symbol and abbre: Implies that stock-level attributes (symbol, abbreviated name) and controller information should be linked via a shared security or company identifier where the relationship is direct and unambiguous; using secucode as the filtering key ensures accurate matching of stock data to its associated controller.
Less than 20% of newly added tradable A: Requires comparing the proportion value to 20 if the column stores percentages (e.g., 20 for 20%) or to 0.20 if stored as decimals; the correct threshold depends on the data representation format of the 'Proportion1' column, which must be interpreted based on domain conventions or schema metadata.
Proportion of newly added tradable A sha: Refers specifically to the ratio of newly added shares to total tradable A shares at the end of the previous period; the SQL filter must ensure that the column used (e.g., 'Proportion1') correctly represents this specific financial calculation and not another related metric.
Benchmark growth rate of LOF funds today: Refers to selecting DailyBenchGR from mf_benchmarkgrowthrate joined with mf_fundarchives on innercode (not SecuCode), filtering for records where type = 'LOF' (not FundType), and ensuring the date corresponds to the current day using a dynamic date function rather than a string literal like 'today'.
In terms of one-year fund benchmark grow: Implies ordering by BenchGRFor1Year from mf_benchmarkgrowthrate, which must be correctly joined to fund and manager data using valid linking keys.
Quarterly growth rate of average per cap: Refers to the growth rate of the average number of shares held per shareholder, calculated as total shares divided by number of shareholders, and its quarterly change must be captured using a field specifically representing this metric (e.g., avgholdsumgrquarter), not a proportion or percentage-based growth field like ProportionGRQuarter.
Major shareholder of the allotment: Refers to shareholders involved in a specific corporate action (allotment), requiring data from a table dedicated to such events (e.g., 'lc_largeshsubscription'), not general shareholder tables like 'lc_relatedsh'.
600165: Represents a security code ('secucode'), not a company code; must be used to filter on 'secucode' field for accurate matching in financial databases where security and company identifiers are distinct.
Benchmark growth rate: Refers to the performance of the benchmark index (e.g., market index) against which a fund is measured, not the fund's own return. Must be sourced from a benchmark-specific table and column (e.g., benchgrfor6month), not fund return metrics like RRInSixMonth.
Proportion of bonus shares: Refers to the 'BonusShareRatio' field, which should represent the ratio of bonus shares issued (e.g., 0.2 for a 1:5 bonus issue); ensure the value is interpreted as a proportion, not a percentage or count.
Amount of cash dividends: Implies the total cumulative cash dividend amount received over the entire holding period, requiring aggregation (e.g., SUM) of 'ActualCashDiviRMB' across all relevant historical records, not just retrieving per-record values.
Annual return rate exceeding 20%: Refers to the actual performance return over a defined single-year period (e.g., calendar year or trailing one-year), requiring filtering on data that corresponds to a specific annual time window, not an unqualified annualized return metric.
Highest benchmark growth rate in the pas: Implies ranking funds by BenchGRForThisQuarter in descending order and returning a top N list (e.g., using ORDER BY and LIMIT), rather than filtering only for the exact maximum value which may miss multiple high-performing funds and does not produce a ranked result.
Equity fund management scale exceeds 10: Refers to filtering on the EquityFundNV column with a threshold of > 10,000,000,000 (10^10) units, typically in local currency (e.g., yuan), representing total net value under management for equity funds.
Based on the weekly fund benchmark growt: Implies a correct and unambiguous join between the benchmark growth table and fund archives using a reliable key (e.g., InnerCode), not SecuCode, to ensure accurate alignment of performance data with fund records.
Grouped by the highest education level: Requires including the grouping column (e.g., education) in the SELECT clause alongside aggregate functions to ensure the result shows both the education level and the corresponding count of fund managers.
Monthly benchmark growth rate: Is stored in the mf_benchmarkgrowthrate table (MonthlyBenchGR), but related fund and manager details are not present in this table and must be retrieved via a join with mf_fundarchives.
Negative benchmark growth rate today: Indicates a filter condition on DailyBenchGR < 0 in the mf_benchmarkgrowthrate table for the current day's data, requiring no date transformation if 'today' is the latest recorded date.
Manager with the highest total number of: Refers to identifying a person in a fund management role by joining a table containing fund-to-manager relationships (e.g., 'mf_fundarchives') where 'manager' is explicitly defined, rather than selecting a name field from a table that may represent fund or organization names.
Name of the fund manager: Must be retrieved from a field explicitly representing the manager's name in a fund management context (e.g., 'investadvisorname' or 'manager' in 'mf_fundarchives'), not from a field like 'ChineseName' which may refer to the fund or entity name rather than the individual manager.
Highest revenue last year: Requires filtering records to the previous calendar year using a date condition (e.g., strftime('%Y', enddate) = strftime('%Y', DATE('now', '-1 year'))), not ordering all records globally by revenue without time restriction.
Stock codes starting with 300: Should be filtered directly on the 'secucode' field in the lc_actualcontroller table using a pattern like '300%', without requiring a join to another table for company abbreviation or controller information.
Actual controllers: Are stored in the lc_actualcontroller table and should be retrieved alongside company abbreviations from the same table when the stock code condition is met, eliminating the need for joining with lc_stockarchives.
Stock abbreviation and security code for: Refers to retrieving the market-traded stock's symbol (AShareAbbr) and its public security identifier (AStockCode), requiring a filter on AStockCode = '600190', not CompanyCode, as CompanyCode represents an internal company ID unrelated to stock ticker lookup.
With dividend records: Implies filtering for rows where dividend-related fields (e.g., bonusshareratio) are not null, to ensure only companies with actual dividend activity are included, rather than returning all rows in the dividend table.
Net interest payment: Corresponds to the 'netinterestexpense' column in financial expense tables, representing the net cost of interest obligations. Sorting by this value in ascending order reflects lowest to highest net interest burden.
Holding quantity in the year 2020: Requires filtering records where the EndDate falls within the calendar year 2020 using proper date functions (e.g., strftime('%Y', EndDate) = '2020'), not string matching with LIKE, to ensure accurate and valid date filtering.
Fund and manager with the most types of: Requires selecting both the fund identifier (e.g., secuabbr from mf_fundarchives) and the manager name (e.g., Name from mf_fundmanagernew) in the SELECT clause to return both entities; omitting the fund results in incomplete output.
Types of bond holdings: Implies counting distinct categories or varieties of bonds (e.g., distinct bond issuers, types, or classifications), not just the count of records in the portfolio table. Should use COUNT(DISTINCT ...) on a relevant bond attribute (e.g., bond code or type) rather than COUNT(*).
After 2017: Refers to years strictly greater than 2017 (i.e., 2018 and later); filtering must extract the year component from the date field (e.g., using strftime('%Y', EndDate) > '2017') rather than comparing raw dates to '2017', which would include part of 2017 due to implicit date conversion.
Stock sector affiliation: Should return a primary or most representative broad concept name (e.g., from a concept table like lc_coconcept), not granular industry codes (e.g., FourthIndustryCode) or multi-level industry classifications that exceed the scope of a general sector inquiry.
Funds hold [code]: Refers to identifying funds (with their names/abbreviations and fund codes) that include a specific security identified by its code (e.g., bondcode='128125'), not filtering holdings by a quantity like SharesHolding = 128125.
Benchmark growth rate greater than 0: Refers to filtering on the daily benchmark growth rate (dailybenchgr > 0), not a different metric such as BenchGRForSince, which may represent a longer-term or cumulative growth rate.
Main operating profit: Is a financial metric typically stored in a column named 'mainoperprofit' in financial statement tables (e.g., lc_mainoperincome), representing core business profitability before non-operating items.
Major shareholders participated in the r: Refers to individuals or entities with significant ownership stakes who subscribed to new shares during the rights issue; data should come from a table specifically tracking large shareholder subscriptions (e.g., lc_largeshsubscription), not general related-party or IPO bid tables.
Actually subscribe for: Indicates the final number of shares taken up by major shareholders in the rights issue, represented by columns such as 'actualshares', not bid or intended volumes like 'ActualBidVol' which may relate to IPO applications.
Number of rights issues: Refers to the quantity of shares offered in a rights issue (e.g., 'actualshares' from a relevant table like lc_largeshsubscription), not the count of issuance events or rows in IPO or seasoned offering tables.
at the end of the period in 2020: Requires filtering records where the year of 'EndDate' is 2020 using a date extraction function (e.g., strftime('%Y', EndDate) = '2020'), not comparing EndDate directly to a year string, as EndDate contains full date values.
Shortest tenure at a fund company: Refers to the minimum duration of employment specifically at an individual fund company (i.e., per-company role), which should be derived from a field representing company-specific tenure such as 'employmentcompany', not total career tenure like 'EmploymentAll'.
year-end cumulative: Requires explicit filtering on the reportperiod column for value 'year-end cumulative' to ensure only true cumulative year-end retail sales data is included, not partial or non-cumulative periods.
Proportion of freely tradable A shares h: Refers to the direct retrieval of the qfiiholdpropa field from the lc_stockholdingst table, which stores the pre-calculated proportion; no aggregation or grouping on this field is needed, but each company should have a single valid record per period.
Shareholding ratio after transfer: Is represented by the column 'PCTAfterTran' in the 'lc_sharetransfer' table, and filtering values greater than 0.5 means selecting records where the post-transfer ownership percentage exceeds 50%.
Tenure starting in 2021: Refers to fund managers whose accession date falls within the calendar year 2021 (i.e., from '2021-01-01' to '2021-12-31'), not just on or after '2021-01-01'. Requires both lower and upper bounds on the date, or extraction of the year component equal to '2021'.
Fund size: Refers to the total assets or scale of the fund, typically represented by a column such as 'FoundedSize' or similar in the fund archives table, not 'FundNature' which describes qualitative characteristics.
Join on fund identifier: Must use the correct linking key (e.g., 'InnerCode') between performance and fund attribute tables to ensure accurate association; using 'SecuCode' may lead to incorrect joins if it is not the primary key or consistent across tables.
Codes and names of the funds: Requires selecting both the fund identifier (SecuCode) and the corresponding name field; while SecuCode is standard, the name field (e.g., ChiName) should represent the official or commonly recognized fund name, and its validity depends on schema-specific column semantics.
Equity shares entrusted: Refers to the total count or quantity of shares represented by a field such as InvolvedTrustSum, which may already contain aggregated values per record; applying SUM() over this field could result in double-counting if not confirmed to be atomic per share transaction.
In the year 2016: Requires exact calendar year filtering using year extraction functions (e.g., strftime('%Y', InfoPublDate) = '2016'), not pattern matching with LIKE '%2016%', which can include invalid or out-of-range dates.
Managers associated with funds: When retrieving managers, avoid unintended row duplication by ensuring the query structure does not produce multiple rows per fund unless explicitly required; aggregate or limit manager representation if necessary to preserve one logical row per fund.
Quantity and total amount of share repur: Map directly to columns 'BuybackSum' (quantity of shares repurchased) and 'BuybackMoney' (total monetary amount spent), which must be selected from the 'lc_buyback' table where the secucode matches the given identifier.
Established after 2001: Requires extracting the year component from the EstablishmentDate using a date function (e.g., strftime('%Y', EstablishmentDate)) and comparing it numerically to '2001' to ensure only companies founded in 2002 or later are included, rather than performing a lexicographic comparison between a full date and a year string.
Third quarter of 2021: Refers to the quarterly period Q3 (July–September 2021), requiring filtering logic that explicitly identifies records corresponding to the third quarter, such as using quarter-based date functions or ensuring data is aggregated at the quarterly level, not just a date range.
Secucode: Stock identifiers like '600649' are typically stored as strings; comparisons should use string matching (e.g., secucode = '600649') rather than numeric equality to avoid type mismatch and ensure correct lookup.
Average distribution of one-year return: Requires grouping fund products by their operation method (type) and calculating the average of 'RRInSingleYear' from performance history, ensuring correct and consistent fund-to-method mapping via a reliable join key (e.g., InnerCode).
Proportion of share repurchases to total: Should retrieve the precomputed percentage per repurchase event (e.g., Percentage field) as a ratio of repurchased shares to total share capital at that time, without aggregation like AVG().
Highest holding of a bond: Refers to the largest quantity or volume of a bond held by a fund, measured by 'holdvolume' or equivalent position size column, not by market value which reflects price-weighted valuation.
Holding of bond identified by code: Requires querying bond-specific portfolio tables (e.g., mf_bondportifoliodetail) using 'bondcode' filter, not equity-focused tables like mf_keystockportfolio which pertain to stocks, not bonds.
Established most recently: Requires ordering by 'EstablishmentDate' in descending order and selecting the top record; the date field must be correctly interpreted as a temporal indicator of incorporation or founding.
Major shareholders of rights issues: Refers to shareholders participating in a rights offering event, requiring data from tables specific to share subscriptions in rights issues (e.g., lc_largeshsubscription), not general shareholder holding tables.
Allotment quantity exceeding 2 million s: Requires filtering on a column representing the number of shares allotted specifically in a rights issue (e.g., oughtshares), not aggregate holding totals like HoldingSum.
P/B ratio: Refers to the price-to-book ratio, which must be explicitly represented by the correct column (e.g., 'pb' or similar); assuming 'PB' is correct without verifying its alignment with financial definition can lead to incorrect results.
In the year 2022: Requires extracting the year from the date field using a date function (e.g., strftime('%Y', EndDate) = '2022') to ensure accurate calendar year filtering, rather than using string matching like LIKE '%2022'', which is unreliable and may include invalid or out-of-range dates.
Highest number of job positions: Refers to counting distinct or cumulative job roles held by a fund manager, typically requiring data from an employment history or experience table (e.g., role titles over time), not merely counting non-unique entries in a single manager table.
Fund manager: Should be identified through a personal identifier (e.g., personalcode) joined between a manager info table and a manager experience table to accurately link individuals to their respective job positions across firms or time periods.
Maximum profit: Refers to the highest value of profit achieved across all time periods or performance contexts for a fund manager; it must be evaluated as an aggregated maximum (e.g., MAX of relevant return fields), not by checking individual return metrics with OR conditions.
Highest number of managed funds: Requires counting the number of funds per company by grouping on investadvisorname in the mf_fundarchives table and ordering by the count in descending order, rather than relying on a precomputed column such as TotalFundN.
Net asset values: Refers to the total net assets of a fund (i.e., total fund size), not per-share metrics like 'UnitNV'. SQL must target a column representing aggregate fund-level net assets (e.g., 'netassetsvalue'), not unit-based valuations.
At the end of the fourth quarter of 2020: Corresponds specifically to December 31, 2020. While this date can be used directly, the query must ensure it retrieves data from financial records aligned with quarterly reporting periods, typically verified via enddate in quarterly financial tables.
Total amount of agricultural deposits an: Implies aggregating the sum of both 'AgriculturalDeposits' and 'SavingsDeposits' columns into a single combined total value, requiring SUM() on each column followed by addition to produce one overall amount.
First quarter of 2022: Encompasses January, February, and March 2022; must be identified using date functions that extract year and month components or compare date ranges correctly, not by string matching incomplete 'YYYY-MM' values.
Frozen equity at each company in March 2: Refers to counting shareholders whose frozen equity period ended in March 2020, identified by filtering on enddate within March 2020 (i.e., strftime('%Y-%m', enddate) = '2020-03'), not those with overlapping freeze periods.
Compared to the industry average: Requires explicitly retrieving and returning both the highest AvgAUM value and the industry-wide average AvgAUM (e.g., from a relevant benchmark table) so that a direct comparison can be presented in the result.
Negative growth rate during their tenure: Refers to the fund manager's own performance metric (e.g., 'performance') that reflects aggregated or cumulative returns over their management period, not transient fund-level returns from a separate fund return table.
Positive fund growth rate during their t: Refers to the performance metric of the fund under the manager's management period, requiring performance > 0 condition on the fund manager's performance record, typically found in fund manager tables.
Proportion of A-shares exceeding 20% of: Refers to the percentage of freely tradable (floating) A-shares relative to total A-shares, requiring data from a share floatation or circulation schedule table (e.g., lc_sharesfloatingschedule), not institutional holding proportions.
each shareholder: Requires including a shareholder identifier (e.g., shareholder name or ID) in the SELECT clause to associate actual and expected share allocations with specific shareholders, not just retrieving share amounts alone.
Highest rate of return: Must be determined by ordering filtered results (after applying performance period condition) by the return value (e.g., fundreturn) in descending order and selecting the top record to ensure accurate ranking within the specified period.
Conducted share repurchases in 2021: Requires filtering records where the year of 'AdvanceDate' is exactly 2021 using a proper date function (e.g., strftime('%Y', AdvanceDate) = '2021'), not pattern matching with LIKE, to avoid incorrect inclusion of malformed or non-2021 dates containing '2021' as a substring.
Average annualized return rate of the fu: Requires computing the average of a representative annualized return per fund, ensuring one value per fund (e.g., by grouping on fund level), to prevent distortion from multiple time-point entries in performance history tables.
Bonds held by 166001: Refers to retrieving bond holdings from mf_bondportifoliodetail where '166001' is the SecuCode of the fund, requiring a direct filter on SecuCode = '166001', not a join on InnerCode or filtering InnerCode by the SecuCode value.
Highest average return rate for one mont: Requires grouping by fund category and computing the average of 'rrinsinglemonth' values from the performance table, rather than retrieving a precomputed or unverified 'FundReturnMean' value without aggregation.
Fund category: Must be obtained by joining with a fund metadata table (e.g., mf_fundarchives) using a shared key like 'innercode', as the category is not inherently present in performance tables.
Investors of a stock: Refers to entities that hold or acquire shares in the company, typically found in shareholder or ownership distribution records (e.g., 'lc_legaldistribution'), not in transfer, trustee, or authorization tables which may include non-investor roles.
Bond holdings: Refers to the specific bonds held in the portfolio and requires returning identifiable bond attributes such as bond abbreviation (bondabbr) or name from the bond portfolio table, not just holding volume or market value.
Fund manager information: Should be sourced from a fund-level metadata table (e.g., mf_fundarchives) that links managers to funds via InnerCode, rather than joining directly with a manager dimension table like mf_fundmanagernew, which may not reflect current per-fund assignments.
Security code '510130': Is a string-based SecuCode used to identify the fund in the bond portfolio table; filtering must be done on SecuCode = '510130' (with quotes for string comparison), not on InnerCode as an integer.
Conducted IPOs in 2012: Requires filtering IPO events based on the year of the IPO date (e.g., using strftime('%Y', EndDate) = '2012'), where EndDate represents the IPO event date, not using LIKE pattern matching which is error-prone and may capture incorrect years.
Each industry: Refers to the industry classification at the time of IPO, which should be sourced directly from the IPO table (e.g., csrcindustryname), not joined from external industry tables that may reflect current or multiple outdated classifications and introduce duplicate records.
Held by the most funds: Refers to counting the number of distinct funds holding each stock (typically via COUNT(*) after grouping by stock), then returning the stock with the highest count; requires proper grouping and aggregation semantics.
Top ten stocks in terms of total share c: Requires grouping by stock identifier (e.g., SecuCode or chinameabbr) and using an aggregate function like MAX(TotalShare) to capture the peak share capital per stock during the period, then ordering and limiting to 10 to ensure distinct stocks are ranked by their highest value.
Benchmark growth rate for six months is: Requires filtering with condition benchgrfor6month > 0 on the benchmark growth rate table (e.g., mf_benchmarkgrowthrate), ensuring data reflects the correct time horizon and metric.
Positive benchmark growth rate for LOF f: Refers to a binary existence check (yes/no) for at least one record where FundType = 'LOF' and BenchGRForThisMonth > 0; should use EXISTS or LIMIT 1 to confirm presence rather than selecting the actual growth rate values.
Actual controllers who are not from main: Refers to identifying companies based on the nationality of their actual controllers, requiring a filter on NationalityDesc != 'mainland China' and returning distinct company identifiers (e.g., CompanyCode) rather than controller names or other attributes belonging to the controller.
Highest commission fees: Requires ordering by commission in descending order and limiting to one result to ensure a single company is returned, rather than using equality to MAX(Commission) which may return multiple companies in case of ties.
Total turnover: Implies an aggregated sum of turnover values, requiring a GROUP BY on company and trade date with HAVING or WHERE condition on SUM(TurnoverValue) > 1000000000, not filtering individual rows with TurnoverValue > 1000000000.
Executive names and positions: Refer to data stored in a separate executives table (e.g., lc_executivesholdings), requiring a join on companycode to retrieve correct leadername and positiondescription; 'TransfererName' from lc_sharetransfer does not represent company executives and should not be used.
Top 5 companies by pre-transfer sharehol: Requires ordering by 'pctbeforetran' in descending order from the lc_sharetransfer table, but associated executive details must be retrieved via join with the executives table to ensure accurate and complete results.
Grouped by the second-level industry: Implies that the query must include the secondindustryname column in both SELECT and GROUP BY clauses to return the industry-wise distribution of company counts, not just the aggregate count.
Average annual return rate: Refers to the average of yearly return rates across funds, requiring a metric that captures performance on a per-year basis (e.g., single-year returns), not the average of 'annualized returns since inception' which reflects long-term compounded performance from each fund's start date.
Annual return rate: Implies a time-bound measure of return over calendar or fiscal years, not lifetime annualized returns; thus, it requires data filtered or aggregated by specific years rather than inception-to-date metrics like AnnualizedRRSinceStart.
Resignation dates are before 2020: Requires extracting the year component from the DimissionDate (e.g., using strftime('%Y', DimissionDate)) and comparing it as a string or converting to integer for numeric comparison; direct string comparison of full date values can lead to incorrect results due to lexicographic ordering.
Listed companies under actual control: Requires counting distinct companies grouped by the controller's nationality (e.g., 'nationalitydesc' in 'lc_actualcontroller'), not by company registration state in tables like 'lc_stockarchives'.
Public mutual fund companies: Refers to entities identified by 'fundcompanycode' in the awards data (e.g., mf_awards), and should be counted directly using distinct values from this field without joining to investment advisor tables.
First quarter of 2021: Requires filtering enddate for dates within January to March 2021 (Q1), not just a single date like '2021-03-31'; multiple year-end dates may exist within the quarter.
Year-end net asset values in Q1: Implies that the enddate must correspond to a year-end valuation date falling within Q1; the query should ensure that only actual year-end records (not all Q1 dates) are considered, requiring alignment between fiscal year-end and the Q1 2021 window.
Largest number of shareholders for a lis: Implies identifying both the maximum shareholder count and the associated company (e.g., by name or ID), not just returning the aggregate value. The SQL must include the company identifier in the SELECT clause and ensure correct filtering by year using date functions on 'enddate'.
Annualized return exceeding 10% since in: Requires using a return metric that specifically covers the entire period from the fund's start date (inception), not an arbitrary annualized return over a different time window; must verify the column represents returns since inception, not e.g., last 1-year or 3-year.
Group and count funds in each category: Requires joining fund performance data with fund metadata (e.g., via innercode) to access both the fund type/category (e.g., FundTypeName) and performance metrics, as category information is typically stored separately from performance records.
Total assets less than 10 million: Refers to filtering records where the 'TotalAssets' column value is less than 10,000,000, assuming the data is stored in standard numerical units (not in millions or another scaled unit).
Total amount of stock repurchases reachi: Requires filtering stock repurchase records where BuybackMoney >= 100000000 AND the transaction date falls within the previous calendar year, determined dynamically using strftime('%Y', advancedate) = strftime('%Y', DATE('now', '-1 year')), not just filtering by amount alone.
Fund investment type: Refers to the investment category or strategy of the fund (e.g., equity, bond, hybrid), represented by the 'investmenttype' field in mf_fundarchives, not the structural or regulatory 'fundtype'. SQL must group by 'investmenttype' to correctly categorize funds by their investment focus.
Top 3 fund managers ranked by registered: Implies returning only the identifier (e.g., abbreviated name) of the fund managers, typically a specific name field such as 'investadvisorabbrname', not including financial values like 'RegCapital' in the SELECT clause.
Annual accumulated industrial output val: Requires filtering by reportperiod = 'annual accumulated' and selecting the appropriate output value field (e.g., industrialoutputvalueap), not just aggregating over time or using raw values without period validation.
Circulating A-shares: Refers to shares that are currently tradable in the market and must be sourced from a table tracking floating or marketable shares over time (e.g., 'lc_sharesfloatingschedule'), not from static share structure tables like 'lc_sharestru'.
Listed companies in the telecommunicatio: Refers to the total count of distinct companies operating in either the telecommunications or computer industries, requiring a single aggregate COUNT over a unified set of company codes to avoid double-counting and ensure inclusion of both industry groups.
Telecommunications and computer industri: May be represented by variations in naming (e.g., 'communications' vs. 'telecommunications') and require pattern matching or inclusive filtering (e.g., using LIKE or IN with multiple variants) rather than exact string equality to capture all relevant industry classifications.
Positive returns in the 'one-month' indi: Requires filtering on a period or cycle column (e.g., indexcycle = 'one-month') to ensure only returns corresponding to the one-month timeframe are considered, not just any record with a positive single-month return value.
Distributed shares: Refers to corporate actions like dividends or share distributions recorded in tables specifically tracking such events (e.g., 'lc_legaldistribution'), not share transfers between parties in 'lc_sharetransfer'.
In March 2020: Requires filtering using standard date functions (e.g., strftime('%Y-%m', date_field) = '2020-03') rather than pattern matching on textual month names, which is unreliable with numeric/ISO date formats.
Circulating shares in A-share market: Refers to free float or freely tradable shares, which should be sourced from a table like lc_freefloat that specifically tracks free float data (e.g., 'afloats'), not total A-shares from lc_sharestru which may include non-tradable or locked-in shares.
Non-tradable A-shares: Refers to restricted or non-listed shares that cannot be freely traded; must be filtered using a column representing restricted/non-listed shares (e.g., 'NonListedShares'), not 'NonRestrictedShares' which represents tradable shares.
Since 2019: Refers to calendar years starting from 2019 onward; requires extracting the year component from EndDate (e.g., using strftime('%Y', EndDate)) to ensure proper filtering by year, rather than relying on direct date comparisons that may be affected by time components or formatting inconsistencies.
Main operating income has exceeded: Implies evaluating the condition (mainoperincome > 100000000) per company per year starting from 2019; distinct companies should be counted only if they meet the threshold in at least one year within the period, requiring year-level aggregation or filtering semantics.
Top ten funds on the 2021 Fund Profit Ra: Requires ranking funds by their total profit in 2021 through aggregation (e.g., sum(totalprofit)), then selecting the top 10; it must not rely on precomputed rank columns like FundReturnRank, as the ranking must be derived from profit values.
Fund Profit Ranking: Implies a dynamic ranking based on profit metrics (e.g., totalprofit), not a static return-based rank; therefore, SQL must compute profits first and order by them, rather than using a pre-ranked table or column.
Newly added tradable A-shares exceeding: Refers to filtering records where the 'NewMarketableAShares' field is greater than 1,000,000, correctly interpreted as > 1000000 in SQL.
Average number of funds managed per fund: Refers to the mean of the 'NumberOfFunds' column directly, assuming it already represents the count of funds per manager; therefore, use AVG(NumberOfFunds) rather than SUM(NumberOfFunds) / COUNT(DISTINCT PersonalCode), which incorrectly reconstructs the average if the column is already at the manager level.
Total share capital of more than 1 billi: Requires filtering on the A-share-specific column (e.g., 'totalashare') rather than total shares across all classes (e.g., 'TotalShares'), to exclude B-shares or other non-A share types.
Free float ratio: Refers to the proportion of shares freely tradable in the market; must be sourced from a field like 'adjfreefloatratio' or equivalent, not derived from restricted share percentages (e.g., 'RestrictAShareP').
Sorted by free float ratio: The ORDER BY clause must reference the free float ratio field directly, which may reside in a separate table (e.g., 'lc_freefloat'), requiring proper join logic to access.
Annual amount of new loans added: Refers to a time-series of values reported annually, requiring selection of both the amount (e.g., SubjectSum) and the corresponding period (e.g., enddate) to capture temporal trends, not a single static value filtered by subject name.
Join on innercode: Financial databases often use 'innercode' as the standardized internal identifier to accurately link fund metadata (e.g., in mf_fundarchives) with performance data (e.g., in mf_benchmarkgrowthrate); using alternate keys like 'SecuCode' may result in incorrect or unreliable joins due to potential mismatches in external code mappings.
ETF funds with benchmark growth rate: Requires filtering fund types to 'ETF' in the fund metadata table and joining with benchmark data on a reliable primary key (e.g., innercode) to ensure accurate association of performance metrics to the correct fund.
Tenure exceeds 1000 days: Refers to the fund-specific management duration (e.g., 'managementtime' in mf_fundmanagernew), not the total employment duration (e.g., 'EmploymentAll' in mf_managerexperience). The filter must apply to the period the manager has managed the specific fund.
Earliest establishment date: Implies ordering by establishmentdate in ascending order and limiting to one result using LIMIT 1 to return a single unambiguous row, rather than using equality with MIN(establishmentdate) which may return multiple rows if there are ties.
Monthly change in circulating share capi: Requires computing the difference in 'FloatShare' between consecutive 'EndDate' values for each 'SecuCode', using window functions or lag operations to calculate period-over-period deltas, rather than returning raw monthly values.
Frozen pledge amount: Refers to the current total value or volume of pledged shares that are frozen, and must be matched to the correct column (e.g., 'involvedsum') representing the actual frozen amount, not 'InitialPledgeSum' which reflects the initial pledged value at the time of transaction.
Ten-year benchmark growth rate exceeding: Refers to filtering on benchgrfor10year > 50 in the mf_benchmarkgrowthrate table, where the growth rate is stored as a percentage value (e.g., 50 means 50%), and should be used without including the rate value in the output unless explicitly asked.
Fund identifier join logic: In financial fund databases, InnerCode is typically the correct key to link fund-related tables (e.g., between mf_benchmarkgrowthrate and mf_fundarchives), as it represents the internal fund identifier; using SecuCode may incorrectly join on security-level codes and produce inaccurate results due to mismatched entity granularity.
Investor type: Refers to the classification category (e.g., 'general investor', 'institutional investor') of a client or entity, not the name or code of an investment advisor. Must be retrieved from a table and column representing client/entity classifications, not advisor metadata.
Reserve deposits: Refers to 'deposits with central bank' in the balance sheet of other deposit-taking companies, not 'ReserveAssets'; the correct column is 'depositswithcentralbank'.
From 2008 to present: Requires filtering using a date-aware condition, such as extracting the year from 'enddate' via strftime('%Y', enddate) >= '2008' or comparing against a date literal, not treating 'EndDate' as a numeric value.
Circulating A-share capital: Refers specifically to the portion of A-shares that are tradable or floating, excluding restricted shares, and must align with the correct column (e.g., unrestricted tradable shares) rather than general 'floating' share columns like AFloats which may not reflect official circulating capital definitions.
Benchmark annualized growth rate since i: Refers to a performance metric that must be explicitly annualized (compounded average return per year since inception) and not a cumulative or total growth rate; the selected column must represent this specific calculation, not just any growth rate field.
Top 5 companies in terms of commission f: Refers to retrieving only the company identifier (e.g., short name 'chinameabbr') of the five highest-paying companies based on 'commission' in descending order; additional columns like 'Commission' or 'CompanyCode' should not be included in the SELECT clause unless explicitly requested.
One-year and two-year return rate: Refers to specific performance metrics typically stored in dedicated fields (e.g., rrinsingleyear and rrintwoyear) that must be explicitly filtered; 'FundReturn' and 'FundReturnMean' are not reliable proxies unless confirmed by schema context.
Annualized standard deviation of returns: Requires scaling the raw standard deviation (e.g., daily or monthly) by the square root of the number of periods in a year (e.g., sqrt(12) for monthly, sqrt(252) for daily), not selecting unadjusted ReturnSD values directly.
Annualized downside risk: Requires applying annualization to the downside risk metric, typically by multiplying the periodic downside risk by the square root of the number of periods per year, rather than using unadjusted DSRisk values.
Since 2022: Requires filtering based on the actual economic event date (e.g., 'advancedate' or issuance date), not the database 'InsertTime', which reflects when the record was entered into the system and may not correspond to the timing of the share issuance.
Total number of A-shares: Requires aggregating (e.g., SUM) Ashares values per company from tables like lc_sharestru, as multiple records may exist for the same company over time; failure to GROUP BY CompanyCode and sum results in selecting individual unaggregated entries instead of total A-shares.
Funds that earned more than 1 billion in: Requires grouping by fund identifier (e.g., secuabbr) and aggregating total profit over all entries in 2020 using SUM(TotalProfit), then filtering with HAVING SUM(TotalProfit) > 1000000000, rather than filtering individual rows with TotalProfit > 1000000000.
excess reserve requirement ratio: Refers to a specific financial metric that must be explicitly filtered in the query (e.g., by column condition on ratio name or type), not inferred from institution type alone.
Proceeds from a single placement: Refers to the actual realized proceeds (e.g., 'PlaProceeds') from completed placements, not planned or projected values (e.g., 'PlannedPlaProceeds'). The query must filter and return the actual proceeds amount to meet the business requirement.
Total amount of retail sales: Requires aggregating (e.g., SUM) the RetailValueOfSCGoods over all records within the past three years for each province and city, not selecting individual EndDate snapshots or returning per-period values.
For the past three years: Must filter records where EndDate falls within the range starting from three years before the current date up to the present, using a dynamic date condition such as strftime('%Y', enddate) >= strftime('%Y', DATE('now', '-3 year')), rather than selecting only the three most recent EndDate values.
Each province and city in China: Implies grouping by both Province and City levels; omitting City in SELECT and GROUP BY clauses results in incomplete geographic breakdown and potential data aggregation errors.
Top 10 companies ranked by interest expe: Implies selecting only the company identifier(s) (e.g., ChiName or CompanyCode) ordered by InterestExpense in descending order with a limit of 10; it does not include the InterestExpense value in the output.
Positive fund returns: Refers to current or general positivity in 'fund return' values without an implied time range (e.g., 'since inception'), unless explicitly specified. Should not assume metrics like RRSinceStart without explicit temporal context.
Annualized fund returns: Refers to the annualized version of the fund's return metric, but only if it is directly labeled as such; should not assume columns like AnnualizedRRSinceStart represent this without explicit alignment to the question’s scope.
Free float ratio of 100%: Refers to exact equality with 100 in the 'AdjFreeFloatRatio' field, which is correctly interpreted as a numeric comparison without conversion (i.e., use 100, not 1.0 or percentage-formatted values).
Scale exceeding 10 billion: Financial databases often store fund scale values in scaled units (e.g., hundreds of millions or millions of yuan), so thresholds like '10 billion' must be converted according to the data model's unit convention (e.g., 10 billion yuan = 100 if stored in hundreds of millions).
Equity funds with a scale exceeding 10 b: Requires identifying fund managers who simultaneously meet both fund size conditions on their respective portfolios, implying a single-row evaluation per manager with both columns (equity and hybrid) above their scaled thresholds.
Two years ago: Refers to the specific calendar year that was two years prior to the current year, requiring filtering by year equality (e.g., strftime('%Y', date_column) = strftime('%Y', DATE('now', '-2 years'))), not a cumulative condition like 'date <= DATE('now', '-2 years')'.
Equity freeze quantity: Refers to individual equity freeze events recorded in the primary table lc_sharefp, where the proportion of total shares (PCTOfTotalShares) and the number of shares involved (InvolvedSum) are directly associated with a specific shareholder (FPSHName).
Equal to or greater than 0.05% of the to: Means filtering records where PCTOfTotalShares >= 0.05, representing the percentage threshold on a per-record basis in the lc_sharefp table, not aggregated or cumulative proportions from separate summary tables like lc_sharefpsta.
Top 5 companies ranked by main operating: Requires selecting only the company name (e.g., ChiNameabbr) and ordering by MainOperIncome in descending order with LIMIT 5; the result should not include the income value unless explicitly requested.
More than one issuance: Implies counting multiple issuance events for the same stock within a specific context (e.g., seasoned new issues), requiring grouping by stock identifier and filtering with HAVING COUNT(*) > 1 on relevant issuance records, not across heterogeneous issuance types without alignment on event type.
From 10 years ago: Refers to records where the EndDate is in or before the year that was 10 years prior to the current year, requiring a date filter based on year comparison (e.g., strftime('%Y', enddate) <= strftime('%Y', DATE('now', '-10 years'))), not positional record selection.
Net value growth rate during their tenur: Refers to the fund's net asset value (NAV) growth calculated specifically over the period a manager was in charge of that fund, requiring alignment of performance data with the exact start and end dates of the manager's tenure for that fund.
Top 5 funds and fund managers: Requires pairing each fund-manager relationship uniquely by tenure period, ensuring that the performance metric reflects the fund's NAV growth only during that specific manager's active management period, not a pre-aggregated or individual performance score.
Highest bond market value: Refers to the maximum market value specifically allocated to bonds in a fund's portfolio, which must be identified by filtering on bond-related holdings (e.g., via security type or industry classification) and aggregating market value at the fund level before selecting the top-ranked fund.
Highest total profit: Implies aggregating the sum of 'TotalProfit' for each fund (grouped by fund identifier like SecuAbbr) over the specified period, not selecting the maximum individual 'TotalProfit' value from a single record.
Records of domestic and overseas loans: Implies selecting only the specific columns related to domestic and overseas loans (e.g., domesticloans, overseasloans), not using SELECT * which retrieves all columns including irrelevant ones.
Before the year 2000: Requires filtering date fields using proper date functions to extract the year (e.g., strftime('%Y', enddate) < '2000') rather than comparing a date column directly to an integer (EndDate < 2000), which is invalid if EndDate is of date type.
Number of pledged shares: Refers to the accumulated or current total of shares pledged per shareholder under a consistent financial definition (e.g., from a dedicated pledge status table like lc_sharefpsta), not a conflation of different share events (e.g., transfers, trusts, initial pledges) across multiple tables with differing semantics.
Companies whose stock codes start with ': Requires filtering using SecuCode LIKE '300%' consistently across the correct source table that tracks pledged share positions (e.g., lc_sharefpsta), not applying the filter indiscriminately across unrelated transactional tables without semantic alignment.
Join condition using InnerCode: The correct linking key between mf_benchmarkgrowthrate and mf_fundarchives tables is 'InnerCode', not 'SecuCode'; using SecuCode may result in incorrect joins due to potential non-uniqueness or inconsistency across tables.
Unit deposits and fiscal deposits: Refer to specific balance sheet items (e.g., 'corporatesavings' and 'financedeposits') in financial institution reports, which must be correctly mapped to their corresponding column names in the database table.
In 2004: Requires extracting the year from a date field (e.g., using strftime('%Y', enddate) = '2004') to include all records from that year, rather than comparing the EndDate directly to an integer or string '2004', which would only match exact or invalid date values.
Issued dividends in 2021: Requires filtering dividend records where the dividendimplementdate falls within the calendar year 2021 using robust date extraction (e.g., strftime('%Y', date) = '2021'), ensuring compatibility across different database systems and avoiding fragile string-based date comparisons.
Price change of the closing price: Refers to the difference between the closing price at the end of the period and the closing price at the beginning of the period (i.e., last minus first), requiring aggregation to compute a single delta value rather than returning raw daily prices.
In the first quarter of 2021: Corresponds to the calendar period from '2021-01-01' to '2021-03-31', which can be filtered using date ranges, but must be combined with ordered time-series aggregation to identify first and last closing prices for change calculation.
Total retail sales since records have be: Implies a single aggregated sum over all historical data for the specified region, but requires confirmation whether the underlying field (RetailValueOfSCGoods) contains transaction-level data or pre-aggregated values; applying SUM is only valid if each row represents distinct, additive transactions.
Underwriting amounts below 100 million y: Requires filtering with UnderwritingSum < 100000000, where the amount is in yuan and no unit conversion is needed. The threshold is strict (exclusive), so no rounding or inclusive bounds should be applied.
Daily benchmark growth rate: Is stored in the mf_benchmarkgrowthrate table and associated with a fund or index via InnerCode; to attribute this rate to a fund manager, the link must go through a fund-level table that connects InnerCode (fund/index) to the responsible manager.
Fund performance during their tenure: Refers to a tenure-based, absolute performance metric stored at the fund-manager level (e.g., cumulative return over the manager's active period), not relative rankings or single-period returns from a ranking table like mf_fundreturnrank.
Top five companies in terms of sharehold: Implies ordering by SHNum in descending order and limiting to 5, but only selecting the company name (ChiName), not additional columns like SHNum unless explicitly requested.
Number of hybrid funds managed by ... re: Requires returning two separate rows or clearly labeled values where each manager's name is explicitly paired with their corresponding hybrid fund count, ensuring traceability and handling cases of missing or multiple records per manager.
Quarterly growth rate in average shareho: Refers to a growth rate computed from the average of shareholding proportions over quarters; requires aggregation of shareholding proportions by company and quarter before calculating growth, rather than using a raw 'ProportionGRQuarter' field without verification of its derivation.
Established after 2015: Requires extracting the year component from the EstablishmentDate field (e.g., using strftime('%Y', EstablishmentDate)) and comparing it to '2015' to include only years greater than 2015 (i.e., 2016 and later); direct comparison of a date column to an integer 2015 is invalid and leads to incorrect filtering.
Average holdings per account have increa: Refers to calculating the percentage change in the average holding value per account over the past six months, requiring comparison of two time-based aggregates; it must not rely on pre-stored growth columns unless confirmed to represent this specific metric.
Increased by over 20%: Requires interpreting threshold values according to data storage format: if growth is stored as a decimal (e.g., 0.20), the condition should be > 0.20; if as percentage (e.g., 20), then > 20 — verification of column semantics and scale is essential.
Stock issuance: Refers to the creation and offering of new shares, which is recorded at the security level (SecuCode), not just the company level (CompanyCode). Queries must filter on SecuCode to accurately identify issuance events tied to a specific stock.
Performance period of 'six months': Filter explicitly on a designated period descriptor field such as indexcycle to equal 'six months', ensuring only funds with this exact performance measurement period are included; do not rely on column names or implicit indicators that may suggest the time window.
Average shareholding proportion: The average shareholding proportion must be computed using AVG(HoldProportionPAccount) grouped by company and, if applicable, by quarter, ensuring the aggregation occurs before any filtering or growth calculations; individual holdings should not be filtered prior to averaging, and the result must explicitly reflect per-company aggregated values rather than pre-summarized data.
Last year: Refers to the full, most recently completed calendar year (e.g., 2023 if the current year is 2024), and must be dynamically evaluated using the year component of EndDate matched to strftime('%Y', DATE('now', '-1 year')), ensuring filters are based on date logic rather than record recency or hardcoded values.
Company names: Refers to the officially recognized abbreviated name of the company, such as 'ChiNameAbbr', which represents the standard display form used in Chinese financial reporting; prefer this over full or language-specific variants unless explicitly required.
Main operating income and main operating: These are financial metrics derived from complete fiscal year periods as reported in annual filings; when referencing 'last year', ensure the data is filtered to the full fiscal or calendar year corresponding to the 'EndDate' to exclude interim, quarterly, or incomplete reporting periods.
Funds and fund managers: Retrieve fund attributes and associated primary or latest fund manager names by joining mf_benchmarkgrowthrate with mf_fundarchives and relevant personnel tables using InnerCode and PersonalCode, ensuring temporal validity through effective date filtering to resolve multiple managerial assignments to a single current manager.
In 2021: Filter records where the year extracted from the EndDate column using strftime('%Y', EndDate) equals '2021' to ensure precise matching of all data within the full 2021 calendar year, avoiding unsafe methods like pattern matching with LIKE.
Ranking of funds: When ranking funds, return only meaningful, human-readable identifiers such as fund names or abbreviations (e.g., 'secuabbr') to represent the ranked entities, ensuring clarity and interpretability; exclude internal or opaque identifiers like 'id' and avoid selecting all columns.
In 2019: Filter records where any relevant date column (e.g., AdvanceDate, changedate, EndDate) falls within the calendar year 2019 using precise date extraction functions like strftime('%Y', date_column) = '2019', avoiding unsafe string pattern matching such as LIKE '%2019%' which can produce incorrect matches due to partial substrings in full date values.
Fund company: Refers to the canonical short or official name of the investment advisor (e.g., as in 'InvestAdvisorName'), excluding full legal entities, descriptive phrases, or identifier codes such as 'InvestAdvisorCode'. It must be the standardized name used to identify the firm in fund documentation, not a numerical or alphanumeric code.
